Plain Fun !","reviewBody":"There's no intellectual challenges made in this movie's plot, and that's how it should be; the characters are only slightly more fleshed-out than any of the ones from the TV show, and that's also not a bad thing - if you put too much seriousness into this kind of film, you wind up killing the roaring-good times to be had. What really makes the film work is the charisma ( & physical charms )of the 3 leading ladies, combined with well-choreographed action sequences and the tongue-in-cheek script. If you enjoy Diaz, Barrymore & Liu ( not to mention Bill Murray )when they're on the screen, you'll love this flick.","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":8}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":178643,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":5.6},"duration":"PT1H38M"}</script><metacontent="

programme.title: 3 Engel für Charlie
programme.desc: Wie bereits in den vorangegangenen "3 Engel für Charlie"-Filmen und der TV-Serie arbeiten drei Ermittlerinnen – in diesem Fall Sabina Wilson (Kristen Stewart), Jane Kano (Ella Balinska) und Elena Houghlin (Naomi Scott), die erst im Laufe des Films zum Team stösst – für den geheimnisvollen Charlie Townsend, dem sie selbst noch nie begegnet sind. Seine Identität ist geheim und Aufträge von Charlie werden stets per Lautsprecher entgegengenommen. Die Townsend-Agency ist mit seinen Agentinnen über die Zeit so erfolgreich geworden, dass das Unternehmen mittlerweile expandiert und mehrere Gruppen mit tapferen Engeln an verschiedenen Standorten besitzt. Angeleitet werden die Frauen von unterschiedlichen Vermittlern – den sogenannten Bosleys (unter anderem Elizabeth Banks und Patrick Stewart) – die ihren Agentinnen die weltweit härtesten Jobs an Land ziehen.

credits.actor: Kristen Stewart
Naomi Scott
Ella Balinska
Elizabeth Banks
Patrick Stewart

programme.title: Die Wilden Hühner
Die wilden Hühner
programme.desc: Directed by Vivian Naefe. With Michelle von Treuberg, Lucie Hollmann, Paula Romy, Zsá Zsá Inci. Sprotte is about 12 years old and has a "gang" with her three friends Frieda, Melanie and Trude. Together the girls take Care of Sprottes grandmothers chickens. The new girl in School, Wilma, wishes to join the group, which Melanie is very unhappy about, and on top of all of that they have an on going revalisasion with a group of boys. Sprottes grandmother is planning on slaughtering the chickens...

programme.title: Little Women
Little Women
programme.desc:
Little Women: Directed by Greta Gerwig. With Saoirse Ronan, Emma Watson, Florence Pugh, Eliza Scanlen. Jo March reflects back and forth on her life, telling the beloved story of the March sisters - four young women, each determined to live life on her own terms." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt3281548/","name":"Little Women","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BY2QzYTQyYzItMzAwYi00YjZlLThjNTUtNzMyMDdkYzJiNWM4XkEyXkFqcGdeQXVyMTkxNjUyNQ@@._V1_.jpg","contentRating":"PG","genre":["Drama","Romance"],"actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1519680/","name":"Saoirse Ronan"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0914612/","name":"Emma Watson"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm6073955/","name":"Florence Pugh"}],"director":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1950086/","name":"Greta Gerwig"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0050868/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0007127/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0532247/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1950086/","name":"Greta Gerwig"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0017301/","name":"Louisa May Alcott"}],"trailer":{"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Official Trailer","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi2655304729","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BY2VjNGY4M2ItNDhmMS00ZTVlLWEyN2EtOWRlNGZkYzMwOTBiXkEyXkFqcGdeQWpnYW1i._V1_.jpg"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BY2VjNGY4M2ItNDhmMS00ZTVlLWEyN2EtOWRlNGZkYzMwOTBiXkEyXkFqcGdeQWpnYW1i._V1_.jpg","description":"Writer-director Greta Gerwig (Lady Bird) has crafted a Little Women that draws on both the classic novel and the writings of Louisa May Alcott, and unfolds as the author’s alter ego, Jo March, reflects back and forth on her fictional life."},"datePublished":"2019-12-25","description":"Jo March reflects back and forth on her life, telling the beloved story of the March sisters - four young women, each determined to live life on her own terms.","keywords":"aspiring writer,poverty,women's rights,death of sister,mother daughter relationship","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt3281548/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"kjproulx"},"dateCreated":"2020-01-24","inLanguage":"English","name":"A Wonderful Film and Gerwig's Best Directorial Effort to Date","reviewBody":"From books to plays, to films, the Little Women story is one of those stories that just keeps getting updated, which isn't a bad thing, as long as they are doing it for a specific reason and not because they are out of ideas. Thankfully, it's very clear that this adaptation was updated for the modern age, which felt like a strong enough reason when watching it. Now, I'll be very upfront with this before diving into my review and state that I don't have any knowledge of this classic material, prior to viewing this movie, so it felt pretty fresh to me. For that reason, you may want to take this review with a grain of salt, but here's why I believe the 2019 version of Little Women is worth your time.

Flashing back and forth between time periods, the focal point of this film is Jo March (Saoirse Ronan) and her writing ambitions. The film begins and concludes with her story, but the rest of the movie places her sisters Meg (Emma Watson), Amy (Florence Pugh), and Beth (Eliza Scanlen) at the forefront as well. All trying to find a man to love and discovering what love truly is, these young women strive to become something greater than how they grew up. Diving into very emotional struggles as the film goes on, there is quite a bit of depth to this story. Loss and relationships are what kept this film emotionally resonant with me and I believe the care that was put into the characters is what made it work so well.

It doesn't hurt that the cast was so well constructed, but I believe the shining star here is director Greta Gerwig. Although I feel that this is a very solid film like all of her previous works (as she has yet to blow me away), she definitely seems to be improving, every single time she steps behind the camera. This is her best film to date in my opinion. The way she was able to bring such raw and realistic performances out of these actresses was amazing. Timothee Chalamet is also an actor on the rise to super-stardom and his presence here was nothing short of fantastic either.

Little Women is filled with some very well-done cinematography by Yorick Le Saux and I also found Nick Houy's editing style to be pretty special as well. With that said, the main thing that deterred me from loving this film was the pacing. There are times, especially throughout the majority of the second act where the movie seemed to really slow down. Yes, these moments were buoyed by effective drama, but I found myself waiting for the next scene to come on a few occasions. This is a wonderful film that I just found to be a little too slow.

In the end, although the pacing of this movie did hurt my experience a little, which doesn't usually happen with slow-paced films, I still was able to really admire it. Little Women is a fantastic effort by director Greta Gerwig and many of the technical aspects stood out to me as well. Quick shout out to the set design and costume work as well, as those will probably be worth of awards very soon. This is a wonderful movie from start to finish and it deserves all the praise it's receiving, but I just didn't quite love it myself. Still, it's a very good movie nonetheless.","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":8}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":156159,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":7.8},"duration":"PT2H15M"}</script><metacontent="

four young women, each determined to live life on her own terms.","keywords":"aspiring writer,poverty,women's rights,death of sister,mother daughter relationship","review":"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt3281548/","author":"@type":"Person","name":"kjproulx","dateCreated":"2020-01-24","inLanguage":"English","name":"A Wonderful Film and Gerwig's Best Directorial Effort to Date","reviewBody":"From books to plays, to films, the Little Women story is one of those stories that just keeps getting updated, which isn't a bad thing, as long as they are doing it for a specific reason and not because they are out of ideas. Thankfully, it's very clear that this adaptation was updated for the modern age, which felt like a strong enough reason when watching it. Now, I'll be very upfront with this before diving into my review and state that I don't have any knowledge of this classic material, prior to viewing this movie, so it felt pretty fresh to me. For that reason, you may want to take this review with a grain of salt, but here's why I believe the 2019 version of Little Women is worth your time.

Flashing back and forth between time periods, the focal point of this film is Jo March (Saoirse Ronan) and her writing ambitions. The film begins and concludes with her story, but the rest of the movie places her sisters Meg (Emma Watson), Amy (Florence Pugh), and Beth (Eliza Scanlen) at the forefront as well. All trying to find a man to love and discovering what love truly is, these young women strive to become something greater than how they grew up. Diving into very emotional struggles as the film goes on, there is quite a bit of depth to this story. Loss and relationships are what kept this film emotionally resonant with me and I believe the care that was put into the characters is what made it work so well.

It doesn't hurt that the cast was so well constructed, but I believe the shining star here is director Greta Gerwig. Although I feel that this is a very solid film like all of her previous works (as she has yet to blow me away), she definitely seems to be improving, every single time she steps behind the camera. This is her best film to date in my opinion. The way she was able to bring such raw and realistic performances out of these actresses was amazing. Timothee Chalamet is also an actor on the rise to super-stardom and his presence here was nothing short of fantastic either.

Little Women is filled with some very well-done cinematography by Yorick Le Saux and I also found Nick Houy's editing style to be pretty special as well. With that said, the main thing that deterred me from loving this film was the pacing. There are times, especially throughout the majority of the second act where the movie seemed to really slow down. Yes, these moments were buoyed by effective drama, but I found myself waiting for the next scene to come on a few occasions. This is a wonderful film that I just found to be a little too slow.

In the end, although the pacing of this movie did hurt my experience a little, which doesn't usually happen with slow-paced films, I still was able to really admire it. Little Women is a fantastic effort by director Greta Gerwig and many of the technical aspects stood out to me as well. Quick shout out to the set design and costume work as well, as those will probably be worth of awards very soon. This is a wonderful movie from start to finish and it deserves all the praise it's receiving, but I just didn't quite love it myself. Still, it's a very good movie nonetheless.","reviewRating":"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":8,"aggregateRating":"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":156159,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":7.8,"duration":"PT2H15M"</script><metacontent="

A young woman strikes up a relationship with her ailing brother's favorite musician." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt2182972/","name":"Song One","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMjM4NDM5NDI1OV5BMl5BanBnXkFtZTgwMDQ4NjE0MzE@._V1_.jpg","contentRating":"PG-13","genre":["Drama","Music"],"actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0004266/","name":"Anne Hathaway"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1926865/","name":"Johnny Flynn"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0005460/","name":"Mary Steenburgen"}],"director":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm2293399/","name":"Kate Barker-Froyland"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0001099/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0093810/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm2293399/","name":"Kate Barker-Froyland"}],"trailer":{"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Official Trailer","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi1359654681","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMjA2MzcwMjI5OF5BMl5BanBnXkFtZTgwNjc2NDI0MzE@._V1_.jpg"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMjA2MzcwMjI5OF5BMl5BanBnXkFtZTgwNjc2NDI0MzE@._V1_.jpg","description":"After Franny's musician brother Henry is injured and hospitalized in a coma following a car accident, Franny returns home after a long estrangement and begins to use his notebook as a guide to how his life has evolved in her absence. Franny seeks out the musicians and artists Henry loved, in the course of her journey meeting James Forester, his musical idol, whose success and fame belie a shy and private man. As a strong romantic connection develops between Franny and James, the question becomes if love can bloom even under the most adverse circumstances."},"datePublished":"2015-01-22","description":"A young woman strikes up a relationship with her ailing brother's favorite musician.","keywords":"musician,recording,sibling","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt2182972/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"cekadah"},"dateCreated":"2015-03-29","inLanguage":"English","name":"A film for Anne Hathaway enthusiast","reviewBody":"Director/writer Kate Barker-Froyland has offered up a deliciously simple yet emotionally complex story of a family drawn together by an unfortunate accident. Karen (mother), Franny (daughter), are forced to reexamine their family status due to Henry's (son/brother) near death accident.

Most of the movie/story is Franny learning about her brother through his notes and songs and interest in other singers and places he visits in NYC. Along the way through this path of discovery Franny meets and falls in love with a folk singer her brother admired.

There are lots & lots of Anne Hathaway face closeups and lots & lots of folk songs. I like Hathaway but the many closeups and folk songs wore a bit thin. That's the reason for the 7 in stars. 

Otherwise this is a fine and thoughtful movie with excellent photography and production values. Please be aware of the lighting throughout as I do believe this is integral to setting the mood of many scenes.","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":7}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":9278,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":5.8},"duration":"PT1H26M"}</script><metacontent="

Franny seeks out the musicians and artists Henry loved, in the course of her journey meeting James Forester, his musical idol, whose success and fame belie a shy and private man. As a strong romantic connection develops between Franny and James, the question becomes if love can bloom even under the most adverse circumstances.","datePublished":"2015-01-22","description":"A young woman strikes up a relationship with her ailing brother's favorite musician.","keywords":"musician,recording,sibling","review":"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt2182972/","author":"@type":"Person","name":"cekadah","dateCreated":"2015-03-29","inLanguage":"English","name":"A film for Anne Hathaway enthusiast","reviewBody":"Director/writer Kate Barker-Froyland has offered up a deliciously simple yet emotionally complex story of a family drawn together by an unfortunate accident. Karen (mother), Franny (daughter), are forced to reexamine their family status due to Henry's (son/brother) near death accident.

Most of the movie/story is Franny learning about her brother through his notes and songs and interest in other singers and places he visits in NYC. Along the way through this path of discovery Franny meets and falls in love with a folk singer her brother admired.

There are lots & lots of Anne Hathaway face closeups and lots & lots of folk songs. I like Hathaway but the many closeups and folk songs wore a bit thin. That's the reason for the 7 in stars. 

Otherwise this is a fine and thoughtful movie with excellent photography and production values. Please be aware of the lighting throughout as I do believe this is integral to setting the mood of many scenes.","reviewRating":"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":7,"aggregateRating":"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":9278,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":5.8,"duration":"PT1H26M"</script><metacontent="

programme.title: Little Women
Little Women
programme.desc:
Little Women: Directed by Greta Gerwig. With Saoirse Ronan, Emma Watson, Florence Pugh, Eliza Scanlen. Jo March reflects back and forth on her life, telling the beloved story of the March sisters - four young women, each determined to live life on her own terms." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt3281548/","name":"Little Women","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BY2QzYTQyYzItMzAwYi00YjZlLThjNTUtNzMyMDdkYzJiNWM4XkEyXkFqcGdeQXVyMTkxNjUyNQ@@._V1_.jpg","contentRating":"PG","genre":["Drama","Romance"],"actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1519680/","name":"Saoirse Ronan"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0914612/","name":"Emma Watson"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm6073955/","name":"Florence Pugh"}],"director":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1950086/","name":"Greta Gerwig"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0050868/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0007127/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0532247/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1950086/","name":"Greta Gerwig"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0017301/","name":"Louisa May Alcott"}],"trailer":{"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Official Trailer","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi2655304729","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BY2VjNGY4M2ItNDhmMS00ZTVlLWEyN2EtOWRlNGZkYzMwOTBiXkEyXkFqcGdeQWpnYW1i._V1_.jpg"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BY2VjNGY4M2ItNDhmMS00ZTVlLWEyN2EtOWRlNGZkYzMwOTBiXkEyXkFqcGdeQWpnYW1i._V1_.jpg","description":"Writer-director Greta Gerwig (Lady Bird) has crafted a Little Women that draws on both the classic novel and the writings of Louisa May Alcott, and unfolds as the author’s alter ego, Jo March, reflects back and forth on her fictional life."},"datePublished":"2019-12-25","description":"Jo March reflects back and forth on her life, telling the beloved story of the March sisters - four young women, each determined to live life on her own terms.","keywords":"aspiring writer,poverty,women's rights,death of sister,mother daughter relationship","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt3281548/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"kjproulx"},"dateCreated":"2020-01-24","inLanguage":"English","name":"A Wonderful Film and Gerwig's Best Directorial Effort to Date","reviewBody":"From books to plays, to films, the Little Women story is one of those stories that just keeps getting updated, which isn't a bad thing, as long as they are doing it for a specific reason and not because they are out of ideas. Thankfully, it's very clear that this adaptation was updated for the modern age, which felt like a strong enough reason when watching it. Now, I'll be very upfront with this before diving into my review and state that I don't have any knowledge of this classic material, prior to viewing this movie, so it felt pretty fresh to me. For that reason, you may want to take this review with a grain of salt, but here's why I believe the 2019 version of Little Women is worth your time.

Flashing back and forth between time periods, the focal point of this film is Jo March (Saoirse Ronan) and her writing ambitions. The film begins and concludes with her story, but the rest of the movie places her sisters Meg (Emma Watson), Amy (Florence Pugh), and Beth (Eliza Scanlen) at the forefront as well. All trying to find a man to love and discovering what love truly is, these young women strive to become something greater than how they grew up. Diving into very emotional struggles as the film goes on, there is quite a bit of depth to this story. Loss and relationships are what kept this film emotionally resonant with me and I believe the care that was put into the characters is what made it work so well.

It doesn't hurt that the cast was so well constructed, but I believe the shining star here is director Greta Gerwig. Although I feel that this is a very solid film like all of her previous works (as she has yet to blow me away), she definitely seems to be improving, every single time she steps behind the camera. This is her best film to date in my opinion. The way she was able to bring such raw and realistic performances out of these actresses was amazing. Timothee Chalamet is also an actor on the rise to super-stardom and his presence here was nothing short of fantastic either.

Little Women is filled with some very well-done cinematography by Yorick Le Saux and I also found Nick Houy's editing style to be pretty special as well. With that said, the main thing that deterred me from loving this film was the pacing. There are times, especially throughout the majority of the second act where the movie seemed to really slow down. Yes, these moments were buoyed by effective drama, but I found myself waiting for the next scene to come on a few occasions. This is a wonderful film that I just found to be a little too slow.

In the end, although the pacing of this movie did hurt my experience a little, which doesn't usually happen with slow-paced films, I still was able to really admire it. Little Women is a fantastic effort by director Greta Gerwig and many of the technical aspects stood out to me as well. Quick shout out to the set design and costume work as well, as those will probably be worth of awards very soon. This is a wonderful movie from start to finish and it deserves all the praise it's receiving, but I just didn't quite love it myself. Still, it's a very good movie nonetheless.","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":8}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":156159,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":7.8},"duration":"PT2H15M"}</script><metacontent="

four young women, each determined to live life on her own terms.","keywords":"aspiring writer,poverty,women's rights,death of sister,mother daughter relationship","review":"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt3281548/","author":"@type":"Person","name":"kjproulx","dateCreated":"2020-01-24","inLanguage":"English","name":"A Wonderful Film and Gerwig's Best Directorial Effort to Date","reviewBody":"From books to plays, to films, the Little Women story is one of those stories that just keeps getting updated, which isn't a bad thing, as long as they are doing it for a specific reason and not because they are out of ideas. Thankfully, it's very clear that this adaptation was updated for the modern age, which felt like a strong enough reason when watching it. Now, I'll be very upfront with this before diving into my review and state that I don't have any knowledge of this classic material, prior to viewing this movie, so it felt pretty fresh to me. For that reason, you may want to take this review with a grain of salt, but here's why I believe the 2019 version of Little Women is worth your time.

Flashing back and forth between time periods, the focal point of this film is Jo March (Saoirse Ronan) and her writing ambitions. The film begins and concludes with her story, but the rest of the movie places her sisters Meg (Emma Watson), Amy (Florence Pugh), and Beth (Eliza Scanlen) at the forefront as well. All trying to find a man to love and discovering what love truly is, these young women strive to become something greater than how they grew up. Diving into very emotional struggles as the film goes on, there is quite a bit of depth to this story. Loss and relationships are what kept this film emotionally resonant with me and I believe the care that was put into the characters is what made it work so well.

It doesn't hurt that the cast was so well constructed, but I believe the shining star here is director Greta Gerwig. Although I feel that this is a very solid film like all of her previous works (as she has yet to blow me away), she definitely seems to be improving, every single time she steps behind the camera. This is her best film to date in my opinion. The way she was able to bring such raw and realistic performances out of these actresses was amazing. Timothee Chalamet is also an actor on the rise to super-stardom and his presence here was nothing short of fantastic either.

Little Women is filled with some very well-done cinematography by Yorick Le Saux and I also found Nick Houy's editing style to be pretty special as well. With that said, the main thing that deterred me from loving this film was the pacing. There are times, especially throughout the majority of the second act where the movie seemed to really slow down. Yes, these moments were buoyed by effective drama, but I found myself waiting for the next scene to come on a few occasions. This is a wonderful film that I just found to be a little too slow.

In the end, although the pacing of this movie did hurt my experience a little, which doesn't usually happen with slow-paced films, I still was able to really admire it. Little Women is a fantastic effort by director Greta Gerwig and many of the technical aspects stood out to me as well. Quick shout out to the set design and costume work as well, as those will probably be worth of awards very soon. This is a wonderful movie from start to finish and it deserves all the praise it's receiving, but I just didn't quite love it myself. Still, it's a very good movie nonetheless.","reviewRating":"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":8,"aggregateRating":"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":156159,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":7.8,"duration":"PT2H15M"</script><metacontent="

Experience the journey of many lifetimes on May 17."},"datePublished":"2019-05-16","description":"A dog finds the meaning of his own existence through the lives of the humans he meets.","keywords":"sequel,second part,animal in title,apostrophe in title,punctuation in title","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt8385474/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"zuriwilliams"},"dateCreated":"2019-05-20","inLanguage":"English","name":"One Of The Best Movies I Have Ever Seen","reviewBody":"This movie is literally one of the best movies I have ever seen. It has to be top 3-5 movies ever. It's up there with movies like Ghost and Lion King. I'm already an animal lover, and huge dog lover, and this movie just gives me more reason to love and cherish my little four legged friends. I'm not going to go into details of the movie in my post because I do not want to spoil it for anyone, but I will tell you this much, bring some tissues with you. Not because the movie is sad, it will be happy tears that you will be wiping away. Just an amazing movie. A masterpiece. I brought my kids to go see it and they loved it. Cane straight home to hug and kiss their dogs. Again....its an amazing movie. One of the best I have ever seen in my entire life. Do not pay attention to these critics who rate the movie low or say anything negative about it, those people are fools. Their job is to critique a movie and look for negatives. Notice the huge discrepancies between rotten tomatoes reviews on movies compared to the public's opinion of a movie........it's always a huge difference. Mark my words, go and see this movie with your kids and family and friends. You guys will not be disappointed. And again, bring some tissues for your happy tears.","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":10}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":20773,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":7.5},"duration":"PT1H49M"}</script><metacontent="

academy","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt0210616/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"preppy-3"},"dateCreated":"2000-06-12","inLanguage":"English","name":"Cliché city, but I LOVED it!","reviewBody":"Let's see--you've got a bunch of young hopefuls in a tough ballet school in NYC--you have the tough, but lovable, black girl; the token gay man; the sweet virginal heroine; the arrogant Russian guy; the sweet lovable guy who's perfect for the sweet heroine, but she doesn't know it; the b**** who's starving herself to death; the guy who loves her and wants to help her; the tyrannical (but lovable) ballet teachers--yep, they're all here! The script is utterly predictable, you know how it's going to end 10 minutes into the movie, but I loved it! The acting is surprisingly good, it's beautifully filmed, the whole cast is attractive and the dancing is simply superb. I wasn't bored once during the entire 2 hours. Well worth seeing.","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":8}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":19292,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":6.7},"duration":"PT1H55M"}</script><metacontent="

programme.title: Think Like a Man Too

programme.desc:
Think Like a Man Too: Directed by Tim Story. With Adam Brody, Michael Ealy, Jerry Ferrara, Meagan Good. All the couples are back for a wedding in Las Vegas, but plans for a romantic weekend go awry when their various misadventures get them into some compromising situations that threaten to derail the big event." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt2239832/","name":"Think Like a Man Too","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMjE2NjMxNjU1OF5BMl5BanBnXkFtZTgwMTI1OTgxMTE@._V1_.jpg","contentRating":"PG-13","genre":["Comedy","Romance"],"actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0366389/","name":"Kevin Hart"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0005517/","name":"Gabrielle Union"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1018488/","name":"Wendi McLendon-Covey"}],"director":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1103162/","name":"Tim Story"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0479739/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0194736/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0010568/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm2226647/","name":"Keith Merryman"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm2226970/","name":"David A. Newman"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0367724/","name":"Steve Harvey"}],"trailer":{"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Think Like A Man Too","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi1893579289","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BOGQ4NzcyNWMtZGRhMS00OGY3LWJiOGUtZGEzMTgwYzNjZTBiXkEyXkFqcGdeQXRoaXJkLXBhcnR5LXZpZGVvLXVwZGF0ZXI@._V1_.jpg"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BOGQ4NzcyNWMtZGRhMS00OGY3LWJiOGUtZGEzMTgwYzNjZTBiXkEyXkFqcGdeQXRoaXJkLXBhcnR5LXZpZGVvLXVwZGF0ZXI@._V1_.jpg","description":"Trailer for Think Like A Man Too"},"datePublished":"2014-06-20","description":"All the couples are back for a wedding in Las Vegas, but plans for a romantic weekend go awry when their various misadventures get them into some compromising situations that threaten to derail the big event.","keywords":"african american,five word title,african american protagonist,black romance,mother son relationship","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt2239832/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"solgrboy"},"dateCreated":"2014-06-29","inLanguage":"English","name":"A great funny movie that treats everyone right. Kevin Hart kills his role.","reviewBody":"I went to see "Think Like A Man Too" last night with a friend of mine. I won't lie, I thought it was going to be some stereotyped "black" movie, and the few white guys that were in it would be the butt of the jokes, and worse, that the "nigga" word would be thrown around like I see it, on occasion, between a few brothers on Facebook, and hear, constantly, in conversations around my very diverse apartment neighborhood and overhear among some African American Soldiers. (I hate the use of that word, no matter who says it to whom, and will not watch movies that dialog it. just sayin'.)

But I digress...Instead of the movies that I have attempted to watch, on occasion, that were what I described above, I found, although this movie could classify as a "Chick-Flick," Think Like A Man Too was really, really funny and very tastefully done. Very little cussing and the one "n-word" uttered in the movie is on a phone call and is barely audible.

This is a great funny movie that really does treat everybody right, the way it should be. Kevin Hart kills his role. Excellent movie for everyone. and unlike one of the reviews I read that said "if you are white and a dude you probably won't get it," All I can say to that is, Wrong. :-)"},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":20041,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":5.8},"duration":"PT1H46M"}</script><metacontent="

Misunderstood, Misanthropic Masterwork","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi2967845401","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMTUwNjc0MmMtYTk0MC00NTNjLWJlMzYtN2U2Njg5MjM2MjZhXkEyXkFqcGdeQWFsZWxvZw@@._V1_.jpg"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMTUwNjc0MmMtYTk0MC00NTNjLWJlMzYtN2U2Njg5MjM2MjZhXkEyXkFqcGdeQWFsZWxvZw@@._V1_.jpg","description":"We're rootin' and tootin' about the Coen Brothers' new movie, but wasn't this supposed to be their first TV mini-series? On your IMDbrief, we look at the misunderstood, misanthropic masterwork that is, 'The Ballad of Buster Scruggs.'"},"datePublished":"1987-04-17","description":"When a childless couple of an ex-con and an ex-cop decide to help themselves to one of another family's quintuplets, their lives become more complicated than they anticipated.","keywords":"arizona desert,reference to arizona state university,state name in title,phoenix arizona,diaper","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt0093822/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"caspian1978"},"dateCreated":"2004-07-31","inLanguage":"English","name":"A Coen Classic","reviewBody":"The Coen Brothers first "masterpiece" black comedy was a 1987 surprise hit that raised the bar in the comedy genre. Future Academy Award winners Cage and Hunter star in what may be one of the most original stories ever to come out of Arizona. Goodman shows the world he can be funny as the misunderstood and somewhat crazy escaped convict. Cage and Hunter have so much love to give, they steal a baby from Mr. Arizona himself. A modern day (80's) fantasy that chooses an interesting setting to tell its tale. The hilarious innocence is non-stop as Raising Arizona showcases relationship, friendship, vanity, ignorance, and the search for peace and forgiveness. Who knows....maybe it was Utah?","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":8}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":129442,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":7.3},"duration":"PT1H34M"}</script><metacontent="

Newman"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0367724/","name":"Steve Harvey"}],"trailer":{"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Think Like A Man Too","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi1893579289","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BOGQ4NzcyNWMtZGRhMS00OGY3LWJiOGUtZGEzMTgwYzNjZTBiXkEyXkFqcGdeQXRoaXJkLXBhcnR5LXZpZGVvLXVwZGF0ZXI@._V1_.jpg"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BOGQ4NzcyNWMtZGRhMS00OGY3LWJiOGUtZGEzMTgwYzNjZTBiXkEyXkFqcGdeQXRoaXJkLXBhcnR5LXZpZGVvLXVwZGF0ZXI@._V1_.jpg","description":"Trailer for Think Like A Man Too"},"datePublished":"2014-06-20","description":"All the couples are back for a wedding in Las Vegas, but plans for a romantic weekend go awry when their various misadventures get them into some compromising situations that threaten to derail the big event.","keywords":"african american,five word title,african american protagonist,black romance,mother son relationship","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt2239832/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"solgrboy"},"dateCreated":"2014-06-29","inLanguage":"English","name":"A great funny movie that treats everyone right. Kevin Hart kills his role.","reviewBody":"I went to see "Think Like A Man Too" last night with a friend of mine. I won't lie, I thought it was going to be some stereotyped "black" movie, and the few white guys that were in it would be the butt of the jokes, and worse, that the "nigga" word would be thrown around like I see it, on occasion, between a few brothers on Facebook, and hear, constantly, in conversations around my very diverse apartment neighborhood and overhear among some African American Soldiers. (I hate the use of that word, no matter who says it to whom, and will not watch movies that dialog it. just sayin'.)

But I digress...Instead of the movies that I have attempted to watch, on occasion, that were what I described above, I found, although this movie could classify as a "Chick-Flick," Think Like A Man Too was really, really funny and very tastefully done. Very little cussing and the one "n-word" uttered in the movie is on a phone call and is barely audible.

This is a great funny movie that really does treat everybody right, the way it should be. Kevin Hart kills his role. Excellent movie for everyone. and unlike one of the reviews I read that said "if you are white and a dude you probably won't get it," All I can say to that is, Wrong. :-)"},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":20041,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":5.8},"duration":"PT1H46M"}</script><metacontent="

objectification,condom,toothbrush","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt0217630/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Aerie-2"},"dateCreated":"2000-08-10","inLanguage":"English","name":""Loser" lives up to its name...","reviewBody":""Let the buyer beware" is a common enough phrase, and it seems this should apply to movie advertising as well. When I saw previews for "Loser", I was expecting a comedy with a spritz of romance and a dash of drama for good measure. Instead I got a hopeless mess which wasn't sure what it wanted to be.

A college frosh (Jason Biggs, from American Pie) is ridiculed by his three dorm buddies, who love to host wild parties and slip roofies into drinks of the ladies. They eventually kick him out of the room, leaving him to fend for himself. At the same time, he falls for a down-and-out classmate (Mena Suvari, of American Pie and American Beauty) who has the hots for her rude & crude teacher. In theory, it sounds great. In reality, it's a lot harder to pull off.

There aren't that many chuckles, and most of them revolve around Bigg's ability to screw up and get laughed at. After a while, you stop thinking he's a geek and actually start to think he's not such a bad guy after all, and why can't something else happen besides him getting made fun of? And why's Suvari still with this teacher for a nerve-wracking hour and a half when it's OBVIOUS the guy's a creep? Basically, Biggs chases Suvari around for 120 minutes trying to convince her to go for him because he's such a nice guy (which is true, but you'd think the girl would catch on quicker).

Add to the mix three moronic dorm buddies who don't even resemble real people (or real college kids, for that matter; all three look to be around 25-30). The only part of the movie I did like was the ending, when an "update" scrolled onto the screen to tell the future fates of these three idiots. I chuckled at that part. If only there was more to chuckle about.

It looks like Amy Heckerling tried really hard to pull this off, but I don't think it's really her fault. After all, to direct and produce a really wonderful film, one has to have a wonderful script to start from. I don't think she had a chance.

If you want a fantastic school comedy, do yourself a favor; Save the $8.50 and go rent "Clueless". So it deals with high school instead of college... it's still better."},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":26822,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":5.3},"duration":"PT1H38M"}</script><metacontent="

The only part of the movie I did like was the ending, when an "update" scrolled onto the screen to tell the future fates of these three idiots. I chuckled at that part. If only there was more to chuckle about.

It looks like Amy Heckerling tried really hard to pull this off, but I don't think it's really her fault. After all, to direct and produce a really wonderful film, one has to have a wonderful script to start from. I don't think she had a chance.

If you want a fantastic school comedy, do yourself a favor; Save the $8.50 and go rent "Clueless". So it deals with high school instead of college... it's still better.","aggregateRating":"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":26822,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":5.3,"duration":"PT1H38M"</script><metacontent="

programme.title: Roxanne
Roxanne
programme.desc:
Roxanne: Directed by Fred Schepisi. With Steve Martin, Daryl Hannah, Rick Rossovich, Shelley Duvall. The large-nosed C.D. Bales is in love with the beautiful Roxanne; she falls for his personality but another man's looks." data-id="main"/><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Movie","url":"/title/tt0093886/","name":"Roxanne","image":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BYjNhY2RkN2YtN2NjZS00YzY1LWJiYzEtYjg4NjJkMDczYzQ4XkEyXkFqcGdeQXVyMjY3MjUzNDk@._V1_.jpg","contentRating":"PG","genre":["Comedy","Romance"],"actor":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0000188/","name":"Steve Martin"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0000435/","name":"Daryl Hannah"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0001685/","name":"Rick Rossovich"}],"director":[{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0770961/","name":"Fred Schepisi"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0055524/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0149490/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0044166/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0744562/","name":"Edmond Rostand"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm0000188/","name":"Steve Martin"}],"trailer":{"@type":"VideoObject","name":"Official Trailer","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi3763780377","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BZTNkNmY5NWQtOGNiNi00ZTUyLTk2MGItZDExZWU4MTdiNjE0XkEyXkFqcGdeQXRodW1ibmFpbC1pbml0aWFsaXplcg@@._V1_.jpg"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BZTNkNmY5NWQtOGNiNi00ZTUyLTk2MGItZDExZWU4MTdiNjE0XkEyXkFqcGdeQXRodW1ibmFpbC1pbml0aWFsaXplcg@@._V1_.jpg","description":""},"datePublished":"1987-06-19","description":"The large-nosed C.D. Bales is in love with the beautiful Roxanne; she falls for his personality but another man's looks.","keywords":"love triangle,unrequited love,female nudity,sexy woman,bare butt","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt0093886/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Lejink"},"dateCreated":"2015-12-20","inLanguage":"English","name":"God's only nose","reviewBody":"One of my favourite Steve Martin comedies, before he followed the example of Woody Allen and stopped with the comedy and hankered after more serious parts in dull films by Ron Howard and David Mamet. This is definitely how I like him best, in genuinely funny situations that make you laugh. He wrote his own screenplay too, cleverly if loosely taking the old classic story of the big-nosed romantic Cyrano De Bergerac and transplanting it to a modern American small town romantic comedy.

As Charlie, the local fire-chief, Martin's character, besides being a loquacious wordsmith, is also, it would appear, a Cirque-class acrobat and martial arts expert which he amply demonstrates as the movie progresses. The arrival in town of intellectual hottie Darryl Hannah finds the two striking up a blossoming if offbeat friendship before the entrance of lunk-hunk Chris, nicely played by Rick Rossovich, to his fire-crew finds Charlie pressed into action as Chris's prompter in trying to win over Hannah's heart in his stead.

Needless to say, the paths of true love don't run smoothly but do eventually find their rightful destinations for all the main parties but not before many highly comedic scenes get in the way. The extended scenes where Martin takes out two insulting tennis players at the start, his top 20 nose-jokes and especially the by-proxy seduction of Hannah at her Juliet window are all hilarious, but there's plenty of devilry in the detail too especially the short scenes with the "Golden Girls" of the town.

Just maybe, Martin could have downplayed the slapstick comedy element of his Keystone Fire Brigade, which can't touch the Golden Silents of Keaton and Lloyd for amusement, but their coming together to finally demonstrate competence in actually putting out a fire, to the strains of "The Blue Danube", at least concluded another minor plot story arc too. Oh, and I hated the sleep-inducing saxophone-dominated soundtrack too, but hey, this was the 80's, I guess.

Martin is terrific in the "Cyrano" part and Darryl Hannah is surprisingly good in being asked to do more than just shake her curls. Mild distraction as they were as a group, it was still nice to see Michael J Pollard as one of the fire crew too.

Like I said, I'm a big fan of Martin's early comedies and this is one of his best. If I'm lying, may my nose grow in length!","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":8}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":41723,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":6.6},"duration":"PT1H47M"}</script><metacontent="

About Schmidt
programme.desc:

A recently retired man embarks on a journey to his estranged daughter's wedding, only to discover more about himself and life than he ever expected." data-id="main"/><script Payne"}],"creator":[{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0046718/"},{"@type":"Organization","url":"/company/co0028247/"},{"@type":"Person","url":"/name/nm1095201/","name":"Louis Schmidt","embedUrl":"/video/imdb/vi3820224793","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","contentUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMzIyMmQyMjUtOWI4Ny00NzZiLWI2NzgtZDQ0YmEzOTk1NTRjXkEyXkFqcGdeQXVyNzU1NzE3NTg@._V1_.jpg"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://m.media-amazon.com/images/M/MV5BMzIyMmQyMjUtOWI4Ny00NzZiLWI2NzgtZDQ0YmEzOTk1NTRjXkEyXkFqcGdeQXVyNzU1NzE3NTg@._V1_.jpg","description":"Theatrical Trailer from New Line Cinema"},"datePublished":"2003-04-09","description":"A recently retired man embarks on a journey to his estranged daughter's wedding, only to discover more about himself and life than he ever expected.","keywords":"minden nebraska,retirement party,recreational vehicle,omaha nebraska,female nudity","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt0257360/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Ford-kp"},"dateCreated":"2006-11-05","inLanguage":"English","name":"Alienated from life","reviewBody":"It is hard to recommend About Schmidt to anyone, without actually knowing that person. Not only does the story seem unconventionally uneventful to most of modern audiences, but it also moves with an unhurried patience that will let many viewers shift in their seats. It really depends on whether one can develop an interest to the film and its subject matter, which shows a retired man suddenly facing the void and meaninglessness of his existence. 

About Schmidt moves slowly, but it moves with grace. The film's success is deeply in debt to Jack Nicholson, subordinating his personality to the character of Warren Schmidt. It must have been difficult for somebody like Nicholson to display the role's required lack of passion without letting Schmidt lose his human touch. Yet, his portrayal is excellent in its understatement, and his numerable supporting actors do not disappoint either. Fans of Nicholson will be assured in their belief, that their favourite is not only one of the best, but also one of the most versatile actors still working today. 

Apart from the acting, director Alexander Payne's film is also well crafted. The somewhat saddened mood is only enhanced by documentary-like shots, constantly making us aware that what we witness is really an everyday-tragedy. The script shows intelligence, and although it contains many subtleties, most of them will not go unnoticed with attentive viewers. Even though About Schmidt is billed as a comedy, it really is a drama. Many of the humorous situations are more tragic than funny, and truly hilarious moments are rare occurrences. 

I've often wondered whether the title of About Schmidt has been chosen with any clear intent. The German surname Schmidt equals Smith in English and is one of the most common. So about Schmidt could actually mean "About Everybody". Everybody can wake up one day and discover that everything he or she has devoted himself to, amounts to nothing. It's a frequent social phenomenon, that people suddenly wise up that their lives are almost over, without ever having fully lived them. Maybe that's how all the sea cruises and world tours of old pensioners can be accounted for. Like Schmidt, they are all making a desperate effort to catch up on a time that's long done and over with.

The film does not exactly give answers and, like in reality, does not end with any true revelations to escape all bleakness. But there is something it often likes to apply, namely the self explanatory power of irony. Like one time during the film, when Warren Schmidt decides to adopt a six-year old African foster child by mail. A cheque of twenty-two dollars, which he dutifully provides on a monthly basis, assures that little Ndugu can go to school, gets sheltered, fed and clothed. Yet, in one of his letters Warren writes to him: "What difference has my life made to anyone? None that I can think of. None...at all!" 

Well, think again, Mr. Schmidt."},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":123833,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":7.1},"duration":"PT2H5M"}</script><metacontent="

Trailer from New Line Cinema","datePublished":"2003-04-09","description":"A recently retired man embarks on a journey to his estranged daughter's wedding, only to discover more about himself and life than he ever expected.","keywords":"minden nebraska,retirement party,recreational vehicle,omaha nebraska,female nudity","review":"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt0257360/","author":"@type":"Person","name":"Ford-kp","dateCreated":"2006-11-05","inLanguage":"English","name":"Alienated from life","reviewBody":"It is hard to recommend About Schmidt to anyone, without actually knowing that person. Not only does the story seem unconventionally uneventful to most of modern audiences, but it also moves with an unhurried patience that will let many viewers shift in their seats. It really depends on whether one can develop an interest to the film and its subject matter, which shows a retired man suddenly facing the void and meaninglessness of his existence. 

About Schmidt moves slowly, but it moves with grace. The film's success is deeply in debt to Jack Nicholson, subordinating his personality to the character of Warren Schmidt. It must have been difficult for somebody like Nicholson to display the role's required lack of passion without letting Schmidt lose his human touch. Yet, his portrayal is excellent in its understatement, and his numerable supporting actors do not disappoint either. Fans of Nicholson will be assured in their belief, that their favourite is not only one of the best, but also one of the most versatile actors still working today. 

Apart from the acting, director Alexander Payne's film is also well crafted. The somewhat saddened mood is only enhanced by documentary-like shots, constantly making us aware that what we witness is really an everyday-tragedy. The script shows intelligence, and although it contains many subtleties, most of them will not go unnoticed with attentive viewers. Even though About Schmidt is billed as a comedy, it really is a drama. Many of the humorous situations are more tragic than funny, and truly hilarious moments are rare occurrences. 

I've often wondered whether the title of About Schmidt has been chosen with any clear intent. The German surname Schmidt equals Smith in English and is one of the most common. So about Schmidt could actually mean "About Everybody". Everybody can wake up one day and discover that everything he or she has devoted himself to, amounts to nothing. It's a frequent social phenomenon, that people suddenly wise up that their lives are almost over, without ever having fully lived them. Maybe that's how all the sea cruises and world tours of old pensioners can be accounted for. Like Schmidt, they are all making a desperate effort to catch up on a time that's long done and over with.

The film does not exactly give answers and, like in reality, does not end with any true revelations to escape all bleakness. But there is something it often likes to apply, namely the self explanatory power of irony. Like one time during the film, when Warren Schmidt decides to adopt a six-year old African foster child by mail. A cheque of twenty-two dollars, which he dutifully provides on a monthly basis, assures that little Ndugu can go to school, gets sheltered, fed and clothed. Yet, in one of his letters Warren writes to him: "What difference has my life made to anyone? None that I can think of. None...at all!" 

Well, think again, Mr. Schmidt.","aggregateRating":"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":123833,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":7.1,"duration":"PT2H5M"</script><metacontent="

programme.desc:

Bales is in love with the beautiful Roxanne; she falls for his personality but another man's looks.","keywords":"love triangle,unrequited love,female nudity,sexy woman,bare butt","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt0093886/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Lejink"},"dateCreated":"2015-12-20","inLanguage":"English","name":"God's only nose","reviewBody":"One of my favourite Steve Martin comedies, before he followed the example of Woody Allen and stopped with the comedy and hankered after more serious parts in dull films by Ron Howard and David Mamet. This is definitely how I like him best, in genuinely funny situations that make you laugh. He wrote his own screenplay too, cleverly if loosely taking the old classic story of the big-nosed romantic Cyrano De Bergerac and transplanting it to a modern American small town romantic comedy.

As Charlie, the local fire-chief, Martin's character, besides being a loquacious wordsmith, is also, it would appear, a Cirque-class acrobat and martial arts expert which he amply demonstrates as the movie progresses. The arrival in town of intellectual hottie Darryl Hannah finds the two striking up a blossoming if offbeat friendship before the entrance of lunk-hunk Chris, nicely played by Rick Rossovich, to his fire-crew finds Charlie pressed into action as Chris's prompter in trying to win over Hannah's heart in his stead.

Needless to say, the paths of true love don't run smoothly but do eventually find their rightful destinations for all the main parties but not before many highly comedic scenes get in the way. The extended scenes where Martin takes out two insulting tennis players at the start, his top 20 nose-jokes and especially the by-proxy seduction of Hannah at her Juliet window are all hilarious, but there's plenty of devilry in the detail too especially the short scenes with the "Golden Girls" of the town.

Just maybe, Martin could have downplayed the slapstick comedy element of his Keystone Fire Brigade, which can't touch the Golden Silents of Keaton and Lloyd for amusement, but their coming together to finally demonstrate competence in actually putting out a fire, to the strains of "The Blue Danube", at least concluded another minor plot story arc too. Oh, and I hated the sleep-inducing saxophone-dominated soundtrack too, but hey, this was the 80's, I guess.

Martin is terrific in the "Cyrano" part and Darryl Hannah is surprisingly good in being asked to do more than just shake her curls. Mild distraction as they were as a group, it was still nice to see Michael J Pollard as one of the fire crew too.

Like I said, I'm a big fan of Martin's early comedies and this is one of his best. If I'm lying, may my nose grow in length!","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":8}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":41723,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":6.6},"duration":"PT1H47M"}</script><metacontent="

for their condescending professor.","keywords":"loser,college student,male objectification,condom,toothbrush","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt0217630/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Aerie-2"},"dateCreated":"2000-08-10","inLanguage":"English","name":""Loser" lives up to its name...","reviewBody":""Let the buyer beware" is a common enough phrase, and it seems this should apply to movie advertising as well. When I saw previews for "Loser", I was expecting a comedy with a spritz of romance and a dash of drama for good measure. Instead I got a hopeless mess which wasn't sure what it wanted to be.

A college frosh (Jason Biggs, from American Pie) is ridiculed by his three dorm buddies, who love to host wild parties and slip roofies into drinks of the ladies. They eventually kick him out of the room, leaving him to fend for himself. At the same time, he falls for a down-and-out classmate (Mena Suvari, of American Pie and American Beauty) who has the hots for her rude & crude teacher. In theory, it sounds great. In reality, it's a lot harder to pull off.

There aren't that many chuckles, and most of them revolve around Bigg's ability to screw up and get laughed at. After a while, you stop thinking he's a geek and actually start to think he's not such a bad guy after all, and why can't something else happen besides him getting made fun of? And why's Suvari still with this teacher for a nerve-wracking hour and a half when it's OBVIOUS the guy's a creep? Basically, Biggs chases Suvari around for 120 minutes trying to convince her to go for him because he's such a nice guy (which is true, but you'd think the girl would catch on quicker).

Add to the mix three moronic dorm buddies who don't even resemble real people (or real college kids, for that matter; all three look to be around 25-30). The only part of the movie I did like was the ending, when an "update" scrolled onto the screen to tell the future fates of these three idiots. I chuckled at that part. If only there was more to chuckle about.

It looks like Amy Heckerling tried really hard to pull this off, but I don't think it's really her fault. After all, to direct and produce a really wonderful film, one has to have a wonderful script to start from. I don't think she had a chance.

If you want a fantastic school comedy, do yourself a favor; Save the $8.50 and go rent "Clueless". So it deals with high school instead of college... it's still better."},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":26822,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":5.3},"duration":"PT1H38M"}</script><metacontent="

When I saw previews for "Loser", I was expecting a comedy with a spritz of romance and a dash of drama for good measure. Instead I got a hopeless mess which wasn't sure what it wanted to be.

A college frosh (Jason Biggs, from American Pie) is ridiculed by his three dorm buddies, who love to host wild parties and slip roofies into drinks of the ladies. They eventually kick him out of the room, leaving him to fend for himself. At the same time, he falls for a down-and-out classmate (Mena Suvari, of American Pie and American Beauty) who has the hots for her rude & crude teacher. In theory, it sounds great. In reality, it's a lot harder to pull off.

There aren't that many chuckles, and most of them revolve around Bigg's ability to screw up and get laughed at. After a while, you stop thinking he's a geek and actually start to think he's not such a bad guy after all, and why can't something else happen besides him getting made fun of? And why's Suvari still with this teacher for a nerve-wracking hour and a half when it's OBVIOUS the guy's a creep? Basically, Biggs chases Suvari around for 120 minutes trying to convince her to go for him because he's such a nice guy (which is true, but you'd think the girl would catch on quicker).

Add to the mix three moronic dorm buddies who don't even resemble real people (or real college kids, for that matter; all three look to be around 25-30). The only part of the movie I did like was the ending, when an "update" scrolled onto the screen to tell the future fates of these three idiots. I chuckled at that part. If only there was more to chuckle about.

It looks like Amy Heckerling tried really hard to pull this off, but I don't think it's really her fault. After all, to direct and produce a really wonderful film, one has to have a wonderful script to start from. I don't think she had a chance.

If you want a fantastic school comedy, do yourself a favor; Save the $8.50 and go rent "Clueless". So it deals with high school instead of college... it's still better.","aggregateRating":"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":26822,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":5.3,"duration":"PT1H38M"</script><metacontent="

Seven years later, she reunites with her best friend, who has been living with a secret: he replaced her preferred sperm sample with his own."},"datePublished":"2010-08-20","description":"Seven years after the fact, a man comes to the realization that he was the sperm donor for his best friend's boy.","keywords":"sperm donor,mother son relationship,best friend,new york city,father son relationship","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt0889573/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"jackgdemoss"},"dateCreated":"2019-04-14","inLanguage":"English","name":"Fantastic actors/actresses casted poorly","reviewBody":"What a strong cast for such an average film. Having the likes of Jennifer Aniston, Jason Bateman, and Jeff Goldblum is a headstart on almost any romcom, but I felt that none of them were the right casting choice for their respective role. Aniston was the only one who felt like she belonged, but like any romcom, a love interest is required and Bateman fell flat. Both Aniston and Bateman performed great, but the lack of chemistry was palpable. The funniest thing about this film was how poorly Goldblum fit into his role. He essentially plays the low-screen time advice friend to consult Bateman's character, yet he maintains Goldblum's "larger than life" persona. I am not typically crazy about romcoms and this one lands right at the median for them in my opinion.","reviewRating":{"@type":"Rating","worstRating":1,"bestRating":10,"ratingValue":6}},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":99742,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":6.1},"duration":"PT1H41M"}</script><metacontent="

owner","review":{"@type":"Review","itemReviewed":{"@type":"CreativeWork","url":"/title/tt0128853/"},"author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Smartypants"},"dateCreated":"2000-09-28","inLanguage":"English","name":"They "Mail"--ed It In","reviewBody":"Saw this movie on cable again, and have to say what an uninspired waste. We've seen this so many times before, and it seemed as if everyone from the Ephron sisters to Hanks to Ryan were just cashing a paycheck. No subtleties whatsoever. The ending really angered me, too. Was it just me, or did Hanks' character spend the last quarter of the movie manipulating Ryan's character needlessly? The final scene would have rung much truer if, rather than sobbing and kissing him once he revealed himself to be her on-line paramour, Ryan's character instead slapped him in the face for screwing with her head. If you must indulge in such romantic piffle, you can see essentially the same movie by renting "When Harry Met Sally." But then you would also get the added bonuses of performances that aren't so paint-by-numbers, some actual humor, and a few likeable supporting characters."},"aggregateRating":{"@type":"AggregateRating","ratingCount":199549,"bestRating":10,"worstRating":1,"ratingValue":6.7},"duration":"PT1H59M"}</script><metacontent="
